In this study, five Ni-doped carbon-based single metal atom catalysts supported by carbon nanotubes, which can be used for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, were constructed. According to their structures, these catalysts include one Ni phthalocyanine (NiPc) molecule, two di- and tri-coordinated Ni-doped carbon nanoribbons, and two di-/tri-coordination Ni-doped graphene, which are denoted as NiPc/CNT, H2(H3)-Ni/CNT, 2(3)-Ni/CNT respectively. We first optimized their structures and studied the adsorption characteristics of CO2 on these catalysts with PBE+D3 method. Additionally, the electronic structure characteristics were then calculated, and the electrocatalytic mechanisms of CO2 reduction to CO, HCOOH, CH3OH and CH4 using these catalysts were studied in detail. It is found that the electrocatalytic activities of these five catalysts for reducing CO2 follow the order of 2-Ni/CNT>3-Ni/CNT>H3-Ni/CNT>H2-Ni/CNT>NiPc/CNT. As can be seen, the di-coordination catalysts perform best, followed by the tri-coordination catalysts, while the four-coordination NiPc-based catalyst performs worst. Moreover, graphene-based materials have stronger catalytic activities than their nanoribbon counterparts. Apart from these facts, these five catalytic materials may exhibit product selectivity at different limiting potentials, and specific reaction products can therefore be synthesized by controlling the potentials. We simultaneously investigated the mechanism of competing hydrogen evolution reactions in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 with five catalysts, and in order to inhibit the competing hydrogen evolution reactions and improve the efficiency of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction, the acidity of the solution can be appropriately reduced. We hope that our present work can provide a theoretical foundation for the future design and synthesis of novel carbon-based electrocatalyst for efficient CO2 reduction. Graphical abstract Five different Ni-doped carbon-based single metal atom catalysts supported by carbon nanotubes are constructed, and the reaction mechanisms of the electrocatalytic reduction of CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4 processes by CO2 with five different catalytic materials are investigated using DFT calculations. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalysis Ni-doped CO2 reduction reaction Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction In recent years, the excessive use of fossil fuels has led to an increase in carbon dioxide emissions, which not only aggravate global warming but also cause great damage to our ecological environment. In order to minimize the pollution of CO2 to the environment, it is urgent to find efficient ways to reduce CO2. The commonly used treatment methods are photochemical method [1–4], thermochemical method [5–8] and electrochemical method [9–12]. Among these methods, CO2 electrocatalysis has attract much attention due to its advantages of controllable reaction processes, relatively simple operation, high conversion rate, easy to scale up production, and higher industrial value [13–16]. However, in the process of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, hydrogen evolution reaction and low Faraday efficiency are still the key points we need to break through [17–19]. At present, a class of promising catalysts are formed by doping transition metals on carbon-based materials including graphite, graphene, nanoribbons and nanotubes (CNT) and their corresponding catalytic performances have been vastly studied [20–22]. Carbon nanotubes and graphene, in particular, are preferred as supports due to their superior adsorption capabilities, extensive surface area, and exceptional electrical conductivity [23–25]. For instance, Ao et al. [26] studied the catalytic materials of Fe, Ni, and Co transition metals embedded in carbon nanotubes, and discussed the detailed mechanism of electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). Similarly, Zhu et al. [27] evaluated a graphitic carbon nitride-supported bimetallic catalyst, focusing on its CO2 reduction activity and selectivity. In recent years, atomically dispersed metal catalysts supported by nitrogen doped carbon (M-N/C) have been regarded as promising catalyst materials in the field of electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction due to their exceptional catalytic activity, high reaction selectivity and long-term stability, which can be obtained by combining transition metals, nitrogen and carbon [28–34]. By distributing cobalt porphyrins atop nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (NrGO), Zhu et al. [35] created a hybrid catalyst and showed via theory and experimentation that nitrogen may efficiently boost catalytic activity to enhance the CO2 to CO conversion activity. Now, materials obtained through the use of independent transition metals (e.g., Ni, Cu, Co, Fe), combined with carbon and nitrogen and subsequently pyrolyzed, have become a new hotspot in the field of catalyzing carbon dioxide reduction reactions, in addition to obtaining M-N/C from metal complexes [36–40]. This novel approach has significantly broadened the horizons of catalytic research. In their investigation into the use of M-N/C (M=Co, Fe, and Ni) wrapped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) as platinum nanoparticle (Pt NP) carriers in the alkali-free oxidation of glycerol, He et al. [41] found that Co-doping with nitrogen and transition metals greatly improved the dispersion of Pt. Wang et al. [42] synthesized a single-atom Co-N-C catalyst (CoN4-CB), demonstrating that the CoN4 sites significantly reduce the energy barrier for forming *COOH. However, the detailed mechanism of the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction process remains unclear. Wang et al. [43] developed M-N/C catalysts, and shown that these catalysts are promising materials for electro-field modulated carbon dioxide capture and separation, featuring controllable CO2 capture, high selectivity, and low energy consumption. Zhao et al. [44] immobilized partially nitrided Ni nanoclusters (NiNx) on N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT) for CO2RR, and the NiNx nanoclusters facilitated the formation of *COOH and lowered the CO2RR overpotential as compared to isolated Ni single atoms. All the above studies are based on DFT calculation. In M-N/C materials, each transition metal atom forms an M-Nx site through coordination bonding with adjacent nitrogen atoms, a feature central to the enhanced electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance [45–47]. It has been reported that Ni-Nx sites exhibit improved carbon dioxide reduction performance and selectivity [48–50]. However, Ni-N/C catalysts with NiN4 sites are disadvantaged by low CO Faraday efficiency (FECO) and low CO current densities at reduced overpotentials [51]. Additionally, variations in electrocatalytic activity and selectivity can arise due to local structural differences caused by high-temperature synthesis steps. Addressing this, Sa et al. [52] prepared NiPc molecules adsorbed on carbon nanotubes (NiPc/CNT) and heat-treated NiPc/CNT (H-NiPc/CNT) catalysts, and the results of experiments and DFT calculations showed that heat treatment changes the in-plane Ni-N4 structure before the untreated treatment into the Ni+-N3V (V: vacancy) and Ni+-N3 structures, the structural change leads to the enhancement of the activity of the CO2RR of the H-NiPc/CNT catalyst, and the Ni-N3V structure is identified as the most probable active site to catalyze the CO2RR, thus demonstrating that the local structure of the Ni-Nx site is altered by the high-temperature treatment and enhances the activity of the CO2RR. However, the detailed mechanism underlying the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction on these catalysts remains elusive, a gap this paper aims to bridge. In this work, we constructed tri-coordinated carbon nanoribbon (H3-Ni/CNT) and nickel phthalocyanine molecularly loaded carbon nanotube catalysts (NiPc/CNT), and designed di-coordination, tri-coordination graphene-loaded carbon nanotube catalyst (2-/3-Ni/CNT) and di-coordinated carbon nanoribbon (H2-Ni/CNT), a total of five Ni-doped carbon-based single metal atom catalysts supported by carbon nanotubes, and also utilize the DFT to investigate their physical properties, as well as the reaction mechanisms of electrocatalyzed reduction of CO2 to CO, HCOOH, CH4 and CH3OH. This study aims to provide a theoretical foundation for the optimal design of CO2 electrocatalysts, contributing to the broader understanding of these complicated chemical processes. Computational details In this paper, DFT was used to study the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction activity of Ni-doped carbon-based single metal atom catalysts supported by carbon nanotubes as shown in Fig. 1 . The structural optimization and free energy calculation were completed using the CP2K software package [53] with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional and Grimme's D3 van der Waals correction method [54,55], during which the DZVP-MOLOPT-SR-GTH [56] basis set and Goedecker-Teter-Hutter (GTH) [57–59] pseudopotential were employed. We choose (6,6) single-walled carbon nanotubes [60] as the initial model for supporting carbon-based Ni-doped single metal atom catalysts. To steer clear of the interactions between periodic images, the vacuum layers larger than 10 Å were added to non-periodic directions. In particular, for molecule NiPc and nanoribbon (H2-Ni and H3-Ni) based catalysts, the lattice parameters of the constructed models are a = 19.742 Å, b = 30.000 Å, c = 30.000 Å, α=β=γ=90° while that graphene based catalysts, i.e., 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT, have lattice parameters of a = 19.742 Å, b = 17.097 Å, c = 30.000 Å, α=β=γ=90° Similar methods have been widely used to study CO2 electrocatalysis and can provide reliable results [61–64]. In the electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide, the change of Gibbs free energy plays a decisive role in each step of the reaction, which is calculated as follows: (1) G = E D F T + E Z P E − T S + ∫ C P d T + G p H In this formula, EDFT represents the energy output by the DFT calculation; EZPE represents the zero-point energy of the reaction; S is the thermodynamic entropy for each step; and T represents the temperature, taking 298.15 K in the standard state. EZPE and S can be calculated through the vibrational frequencies of adsorbed intermediates. The entropy S of adsorbed molecules is also available from the NIST database. The integral ∫CPdT represents the thermodynamic enthalpy of vibration from 0 to 298.15 K. GpH is the pH correction of free energy, calculated by the formula GpH =kBT × ln10 × pH (kB stands for Boltzmann constant). Generally, the pH value is set to 0 in acidic conditions [65]. The calculation methods related to the stability of reaction intermediates in electrocatalysis are all derived from Nørskov's research [66,67]. The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of electrocatalysis is calculated regarding the hydrogen electrode model. Its expression is as follows: (2) H + + e − ⇌ 1 / 2 H 2 ( g ) Δ G = 0 eV In this model, comparing reversible hydrogen electrodes at different pH values, the reaction reaches equilibrium when the electrode potential is 0 V (ΔG=0 eV). Therefore, when calculating the free energy of a step reaction, H ++e − can be replaced by the free energy of 1/2H2. That is to say, the reaction *X + 1/2H2(g)=XH can be replaced by the reaction *X + H ++e −=XH (* represents the surface adsorption site). In the adsorption process, a part of the energy will be released. It is called the adsorption energy(Eads) and can be calculated as: (3) E a d s = E t o t a l − E s l a b − E a d where Etotal represents the total energy of the adsorbed substance adsorbed on the surface, Eslab represents the energy of the adsorbed surface alone, and Ead represents the energy of an adsorbed substance. The limiting potential (UL) is the maximum free energy change in the lowest free reaction path that ensures the free energy difference is less than zero at each downhill step in the reaction path [68,69], and the UL can be obtained by -ΔGmax /ne, where -ΔGmax is the value of the free energy difference of the rate-limiting step, n is the number of transferred charges, and e is the elementary charge [70]. The overpotential (η) is calculated from the difference between the equilibrium potential (Ue) and limiting potential (UL) [71,72]: (4) η = U e − U L Results and discussion Catalyst structure and CO2 adsorption characteristics Previous experiments have shown that after adsorption of NiPc molecules on carbon nanotubes, high-activity electrocatalytic CO2 catalytic material can be obtained through heat treatment [45]. Since the final structures after heat treatment remain unclear, we have constructed five possible structures to explore their catalytic properties, including the one NiPc/CNT, two carbon nanoribbon based catalysts with di- and tri-coordination patterns, namely H2-Ni/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT, and two graphene based catalysts with di- and tri-coordination patterns, namely 2-Ni/CNT and 3-Ni/CNT. The optimized structures are shown in Fig. 1. It can be seen that the graphene based structures are more rigid than those nanoribbon-based structures. As shown in Fig. 1, the distances between Ni atoms and N atoms are also different from each other in the five catalyst models. The results show that in the NiPc/CNT catalyst structure, four N atoms are bound to Ni atoms at distances of 1.904 Å, 1.905 Å, 1.907 Å, and 1.914 Å. In the H3-Ni/CNT catalyst structure, three N atoms are bound to Ni atoms at distances of 1.778 Å, 1.829 Å, and 1.845 Å. Meanwhile, the three N atoms in the 3-Ni/CNT catalyst complex are separated from the Ni atom by 1.912 Å, 1.880 Å, and 1.825 Å. In the H2-Ni/CNT catalyst structure, the two N atoms are located at distances of 1.814 Å and 1.800 Å from the Ni atom. The distance between the two N atoms and the Ni atom in the 2-Ni/CNT catalyst structure is 1.848 Å and 1.851 Å, respectively. Comparatively, the distances between the Ni atom and the coordination N atoms in the rigid carbon-based catalyst structure increase. We then optimized the adsorption configurations of CO2 on five different catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2 . When CO2 is adsorbed on NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts, with bond angles of 179.2°, 178.1°, 177.5°, 178.5°, and 178.3°. Correspondingly, the distances between the C atoms of CO2 and the catalyst Ni atoms in the adsorption structure measure 3.042 Å, 2.958 Å, 2.902 Å, 3.149 Å, and 2.835 Å. At the same time, we also calculated the adsorption energy of CO2 molecules adsorbed on these five catalyst structures and the adsorption energies of CO2 molecules on NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts are −0.22 eV, −0.17 eV, −0.25 eV, −0.18 eV and −0.17 eV, respectively. Evidently, the adsorption capacity of the H2-Ni /CNT catalyst for CO2 is relatively strong. The change in bond angle between adsorption energy and CO2 indicates that the five catalysts possess a certain capacity for CO2 adsorption. Among these, H2-Ni/CNT has the highest adsorption energy, and it also shows the largest change in bond angle following CO2 adsorption. This suggests that the H2-Ni/CNT catalyst has the strongest effect on CO2 activation during the adsorption process. Mechanism of electrocatalytic reduction of NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts to C1 products Understanding the formation mechanism of different products in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is conducive to the development of efficient catalysts. Firstly, we study the reduction mechanism of two catalysts, NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT, to reduce CO2 to the four C1 products, CO, HCOOH, CH3OH and CH4, as shown in Fig. S1. We optimize the stable adsorption structures of all possible intermediates in the CO2RR path on the NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts, and the stable configurations are obtained as shown in Fig. S2, and the step-by-step free energy changes for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 by the catalyst are listed in Table 1 . The electrocatalytic reaction process of CO2 reduction to CO and HCOOH catalyzed by NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts is as follows: CO2 is adsorbed and activated on the catalyst surface to form *CO2 (* denotes the catalyst adsorption surface). Then *CO2 gains an electron (e −) and binds to a proton (H +) to form an intermediate product *COOH or *OCHO. The difference in the formation of *COOH and *OCHO intermediates lies in the adsorption configuration of carbon dioxide in the initial state. When the C atom in *CO2 adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst accepts protons to form the intermediate *OCHO, and the O atom in *CO2 accepts protons to form the intermediate *COOH, this process is usually a thermodynamic non-spontaneous process. It can be seen from Table 1 that the change values of free energy of NiPc/CNT catalyst in the above reaction steps *CO2+H ++e −→*COOH and *CO2+H ++e −→*OCHO are 1.81 eV and 2.20 eV, respectively. Later, *COOH further gains an electron (e −) and combines with a proton (H +) to form *HCOOH or loses an H2O to form *CO. The free energy change during the reaction *COOH+H ++e −→*HCOOH is −1.52 eV, while the free energy change during the reaction *COOH+H ++e −→*CO+H2O is −0.72 eV. *OCHO can also gain an electron (e −) and bind with a proton (H +), leading to the formation of *HCOOH. The reaction pathway is represented as *OCHO+H ++e −→*HCOOH, with a free energy change of −1.91 eV. Given that the production of the *OCHO intermediate necessitates a substantial free energy change, the predominant pathway for HCOOH formation catalyzed by NiPc/CNT is *CO2→*COOH→*HCOOH, while the pathway for *CO formation is mainly *CO2→*COOH→*CO. Similar to the catalyst NiPc/CNT, the free energy change of H3-Ni/CNT catalyst reaction step *CO2+H ++e −→*COOH is 1.39 eV, while the free energy change of step *CO2+H ++e −→*OCHO is 1.76 eV. And a comparison of the free energy change values of generating the two intermediate products of the free energy change values the two intermediate products based on the free energy change values, it is found that the H3-Ni/CNT catalyst generates *OCHO with a higher reaction free energy difference value, and like the catalyst NiPc/CNT, the intermediate product *COOH is more easily generated. H3-Ni/CNT catalyst changes to −1.01 eV during the *COOH+H ++e −→*HCOOH reaction. The free energy change for *COOH+H ++e −→*CO+H2O is −0.45 eV. The intermediate *OCHO gains an electron (e −) and combines with a proton (H +) to form *HCOOH, so the reaction step is *OCHO+H ++e −→*HCOOH, and the free energy of the reaction changes to −1.38 eV. H3-Ni/CNT and NiPc/CNT catalysts have the same catalytic reaction mechanism, with the primary pathway for HCOOH formation being *CO2→*COOH→*HCOOH and for *CO production being *CO2→*COOH→*CO. The change value in free energy for the rate-limiting step with the H3-Ni/CNT catalyst in the process of CO generation is smaller than the catalyst NiPc/CNT, so H3-Ni/CNT is easier to electrocatalyze CO2 reduction to produce CO than NiPc/CNT. The free energy changes of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction to CO and HCOOH are shown in Fig. 3 . The rate-limiting step for CO production with the two catalysts, NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT, during CO2 reduction, is *CO2+H ++e −→*COOH, the change of reaction free energy is 1.39 eV and 1.81 eV, respectively, which is consistent with the results of SA [52]. According to the reduction path shown in Fig. S1, the change of free energy of the reaction path for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH3OH by NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts is shown in Fig. 4 . For catalyst H3-Ni/CNT, during the reduction reaction of CH3OH, CO2 is first reduced to *HCOOH or *CO, and the *CO adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst further gains electrons to combine with an H + to form the intermediate *CHO or *COH, while *HCOOH gains electrons and combines with an H + to lose an H2O to form the intermediate *CHO. Since the formation of *COH has a high free energy change (0.81 eV), *HCOOH obtains an electron to bind a proton and removes a water molecule to generate *CHO, and the reaction step is *HCOOH+H ++e −→*CHO+H2O, and the reaction free energy change is 0.27 eV. The reaction step is *CO+H ++e −→*CHO, with a free energy change of −0.28 eV, thus *CHO can be used as the main intermediate in the subsequent reaction, and the *CHO intermediates form *CHOH or *CH2O intermediates, respectively. Under the action of H3-Ni/CNT catalyst, the change of free energy during the reaction of *CHO+H ++e −→*CH2O is 0.16 eV, and the free energy variation during the *CHO to *CHOH reaction is observed to be 0.70 eV. Comparing the free energy variation values of the two intermediates, it becomes apparent that generating *CH2O intermediates is relatively easier. In the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, both *CHOH and *CH2O serve as crucial reduction intermediates. *CHOH undergoes exclusive reduction to *CH2OH, entailing a free energy shift of −0.49 eV, followed by its subsequent reduction to *CH3OH, marked by a 0.50 eV. *CH2O can be reduced to *OCH3 in addition to being further reduced to *CH2OH. *CH2O further gains an electron and proton to forming intermediate *CH2OH or *OCH3, and the intermediates *CH2OH or *OCH3, adsorbed on the C or O atoms respectively, combine with an electron and a proton to form the *CH3OH intermediate. The change value of the free energy of *CH2O+H ++e −→*CH2OH reaction is 0.05 eV; the free energy change value of *CH2O+H ++e −→*OCH3 is −0.32 eV, and comparing the free energy change value of the two intermediates, it is found that *OCH3 intermediate are more easily formed from *CH2O. The intermediate *OCH3 is further reduced to *CH3OH in the reaction step *OCH3+H ++e −→*CH3OH, the free energy of the reaction changes to −2.02 eV. CH3OH is dissociated from the catalyst to form CH3OH molecules. According to the analysis of the change of reaction free energy, the reaction path of catalyst H3-Ni/CNT to reduce CO2 to CH3OH is CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CH2O→*OCH3→CH3OH. Like the action mechanism of H3-Ni/CNT catalyst, NiPc/CNT catalyst electrocatalyzes the reaction process of reducing CO2 to CH3OH, after the formation of *HCOOH and *CO, the formation of *COH has a high free energy, up to 2.87 eV. Therefore, *CHO is used as the main intermediate for the subsequent reaction process. The catalyst NiPc/CNT generates *CHO by the steps *HCOOH+H ++e −→*CHO+H2O or *CO+H ++e −→*CHO, and the free energy changes for the reactions are 1.20 eV and 0.40 eV. Afterwards *CHO can be reduced to *CH2O or *CHOH intermediates, with a free energy of −0.83 eV for the reation step *CHO+H ++e −→*CH2O; and a value of 1.42 eV for the reaction step *CHO+H ++e −→*CHOH. Relatively speaking, the formation of *CHOH requires a high change in free energy, *CHOH can be further reduced to *CH2OH, and *CH2OH receives a proton and an electron to generate *CH3OH. The reaction steps are *CHOH+H ++e −→*CH2OH and *CH2OH+H ++e −→CH3OH, with the free energy changes for these steps being −1.47 eV and 0.20 eV. *CH2O can further gain an electron and a proton to form either an intermediate *CH2OH or *OCH3. In the NiPc/CNT catalyst, the free energy changes for the reaction steps *CH2O+H ++e −→*CH2OH and *CH2O+H ++e −→*OCH3 are 0.78 eV and 0.76 eV. Finally, the transformation of *CH2OH and *OCH3 to *CH3OH involves free energy changes of 0.20 eV and −2.02 eV. Finally, methanol is dissociated from the catalyst to form CH3OH molecules. The reaction pathway for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH3OH over NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts is CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CH2O→*OCH3→CH3OH. CH4 can be generated through two different paths. According to the mechanism Fig. S1, one of the paths takes the intermediate *CH2OH as the starting point of the reaction and generates CH4 through the process of *CH2OH→*CH2→*CH3→*CH4, which is a competitive reaction process of methanol generation. After *CH2OH obtains an electron, H no longer binds to C to form CH3OH, but binds to O. At the same time, the C-O bond breaks, leading to the departure of the resulting H2O molecule from the catalytic surface and forming the intermediate *CH2. This reaction proceeds as *CH2OH+H ++e −→*CH2+H2O, with the free energy changes for NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts being 0.98 eV and 0.77 eV. *CH2 then undergoes protonation and electronization to form the reducing intermediate *CH3, where the free energy for NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT shifts to −1.82 eV and −1.81 eV. Subsequently, *CH3 acquires a proton and an electron to form CH4. In this step, the reaction for the two catalysts NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT, represented as *CH3+H ++e −→CH4, involves a free energy change of −1.94 eV for NiPc/CNT and −1.09 eV for H3-Ni/CNT. The other path takes the intermediate *OCH3 as the starting point, and the reaction process is *OCH3→*CH4+*O→*OH→H2O, and the change of free energy of CH4 generation by the reaction is shown in Fig. 5 . *OCH3 initially gains an electron and combines with an H +. If H + combines with O at this stage, a CH3OH molecule is formed. Alternatively, if H + combines with C after *OCH3 gains an electron, the C-O bond breaks, leading to the rapid departure of the generated CH4 from the catalytic surface, while the O atom remains adsorbed on the catalyst surface (denoted as *O) to continue the subsequent reduction process. This reaction, represented as *OCH3+H ++e −→*O+CH4, undergoes a change in reaction free energy of 1.56 eV for NiPc/CNT and 1.47 eV for H3-Ni/CNT. Furthermore, *O can acquire an additional electron and proton to form *OH, which is eventually reduced to H2O. During the *O + H ++e −→*OH reaction, the free energy changes for NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts are −2.66 eV and −2.09 eV. Then *OH is reduced to H2O and the reaction process is *OH+H ++e −→H2O, the free energy of this process changes to −2.04 eV and −1.62 eV. Comparing the change of free energy between the two reaction paths to generate CH4, the optimal reaction path of CO2 reduction to CH4 by NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts is *CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CH2O→*CH2OH→*CH2→*CH3→*CH4. Chen et al. [65] studied the CO2 reduction mechanism of Co-C3N4, Fe-C3N4 and Ni-C3N4 catalysts, and found that the main reaction path of Ni-C3N4 catalyst when reducing CO2 to CH4 is protonation of *OCH3 into *O intermediates and CH4 is regenerated, which is different from our results. Mechanism of electrocatalytic reduction of H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts to C1 products We further study the mechanism of electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to C1 product by H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts. The stable adsorption structures of all possible intermediates in the CO2RR path on the three catalysts are optimized, and the stable configurations are obtained, as shown in Fig. S3. The free energies of all the stable adsorption structures are calculated, and the step-by-step free energy changes of three catalysts for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 are listed in Table 2 . The H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts electrocatalytically reduce CO2 to CO and HCOOH after two processes of obtaining electrons and protons.CO2 is first adsorbed on the catalyst surface for activation, and then forms either *COOH or *OCHO intermediates, and finally forms *HCOOH or *CO. The free energies for the electrocatalytic reduction to CO and HCOOH by H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts are depicted in Fig. S4. The comparison of the free energy changes in the reduction of CO2 to two intermediates, *COOH and *OCHO, using three different catalysts revealed that all three catalysts exhibit lower free energy changes in the step *CO2+H ++e −→*COOH. This is consistent with the mechanisms of the catalysts NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT, indicating that the intermediate *COOH is more readily formed. Subsequently, the *COOH intermediate is further reduced to CO and HCOOH. Therefore, the reaction pathways for the formation of CO and HCOOH with the catalysts H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT are *CO2→*COOH→*CO and *CO2→*COOH→*HCOOH. The first two steps of electrocatalytic reduction of H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts to CH3OH are the same as the process of HCOOH and CO formation. The free energy changes of H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts for electrocatalytic reduction to CH3OH are shown in Fig. S5. For the H2-Ni/CNT and 3-Ni/CNT catalysts in the reduction reaction to CH3OH, CO2 is initially reduced to *HCOOH or *CO. In the next step, *HCOOH can only be reduced to the intermediate *CHO. From the *CHO intermediate, either *CHOH or *CH2O intermediates can be formed. By comparing the free energy changes of these two steps, it is found that the formation of the *CH2O intermediate is more favorable, consistent with the catalysts NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT. Subsequently, *CH2O acquires an electron and a proton, forming either the *CH2OH or *CH3O intermediate. In this process, comparing the free energy changes of these two steps reveals that the *CH2OH intermediate is more readily formed. Therefore, for the H2-Ni/CNT and 3-Ni/CNT catalysts, the reaction pathway for converting CO2 to CH3OH is CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CH2O→*CH2OH→CH3OH. For the 2-Ni/CNT catalyst, when comparing the free energy changes in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to *HCOOH and *CO, it is found that *CO is more readily formed. The *CO intermediate undergoes further reduction to form either *COH or *CHO. However, the formation of *COH involves a higher free energy change, making the formation of *CHO more favorable. Upon comparing the free energy changes for the formation of the intermediates *CHOH and *CH2O, it is observed that *CHOH is more easily formed. Subsequently, this intermediate acquires an electron and a proton, leading to the formation of CH3OH. Therefore, the reaction pathway for the 2-Ni/CNT catalyst is CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CHOH→*CH2OH→CH3OH, which differs from the mechanisms of H2-Ni/CNT and 3-Ni/CNT catalysts. In the CH4 production pathways using the H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts, due to the relatively large free energy change in forming the *OCH3 intermediate, these catalysts all proceed with the reduction starting from the *CH2OH intermediate, in a manner similar to the NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts. From the reaction path diagram in Fig. S1, the three catalysts of 3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT will all undergo the *CH2OH→*CH2→*CH3→*CH4 process. In the CH4 production pathways using the H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts, due to the relatively large free energy change in forming the *OCH3 intermediate, these catalysts all proceed with the reduction starting from the *CH2OH intermediate, in a manner similar to the NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts. Comprehensively comparing the changes of catalytic free energy, the best path for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4 by H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts is CO2→*COOH→*CO→*CHO→*CH2O→*CH2OH→*CH2→*CH3→CH4. The free energy diagram of the reaction path is shown in Fig. S6. Similar to the reaction mechanism of CO2 catalyzed reduction to CH4 studied by Voiry [73] and Xie et al. [74] the three catalysts generate CH4 through the process of *CH2OH→*CH2→*CH3→CH4. The limiting potential (UL) is the maximum free energy change in a reaction pathway and can characterize the activity strength of an electrocatalyst. The limiting potentials for five catalysts catalyzing the reduction of CO2 to CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4 are listed in Table 3 . According to Table 3, the rate-limiting step for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO and HCOOH for all five catalysts is *CO+H ++e −→*COOH, with the limiting potentials for NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts being 1.81 V, 1.39 V, 1.62 V, 0.82 V, and 0.21 V, respectively. The H3-Ni/CNT catalyst shows stronger activity than the NiPc/CNT catalyst in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO and HCOOH. For the reduction of CO2 to CH3OH and CH4, the rate-limiting step for both NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT is also *CO+H ++e −→*COOH, with limiting potentials of 1.81 V and 1.39 V, respectively. This also indicates a stronger catalytic activity for the H3-Ni/CNT catalyst, consistent with the results reported in experimental studies. For H2-Ni/CNT, the rate-limiting step in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH3OH and CH4 is *CO+H ++e −→*COOH, with a relatively high limiting potential of 1.62 V, indicating poor selectivity of this catalyst for the reaction. For the 3-Ni/CNT catalyst, the rate-limiting steps in the electrocatalytic reduction to CH3OH and CH4 are *CO+H ++e −→*COOH and *CH2OH+H ++e −→*CH2+H2O, respectively, with limiting potentials of 0.82 V and 1.39 V. This suggests that the 3-Ni/CNT catalyst has higher selectivity for CH3OH, favoring its production. Similarly, the 2-Ni/CNT catalyst also exhibits higher selectivity for CH3OH. By comparing the UL values, the catalytic activity of the three catalysts H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to four different products CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4 can be assessed. It is found that 2-Ni/CNT has the highest catalytic activity, while H2-Ni/CNT has relatively lower activity. Comparing with experimental results, the UL values for NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT catalysts are 1.81 and 1.39 V, respectively, which are higher than those of the newly designed catalysts H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT. Therefore, the performance of the three newly designed electrocatalysts in catalyzing CO2 has been improved. From the UL values, it is evident that 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT have stronger catalytic selectivity for the reduction of CO2 to four different C1 products. In order to further confirm the adsorption characteristics of CO2 on the surface of the five catalysts, we calculated the charge density difference (CDD) between the five catalysts and CO2 respectively. As shown in Fig. 6 , green denotes a decrease in electron density and yellow, an increase in electron density. It can be seen that some electrons are transferred from the catalyst to CO2. CDD shows that there is an obvious electron transfer process during the adsorption of CO2 on the five catalysts. By calculating the energy band structures(EBS) and density of states (DOS) for five different catalyst structures, NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT, which is shown in Fig. S7, the relationship between the structural characteristics of the catalyst and its catalytic activity is further explored. The red dashed line in the figure is the Fermi energy level, and the Fermi energy level in the DOS diagram is related to the catalytic activity; the higher the density of the electron cloud, the stronger the catalytic activity [75]. DOS calculations show that for the two 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts with graphene as the carbon substrate material, the charge densities at the Fermi energy level are 92.07 eV and 126.61 eV, and the Fermi energy level of the 2-Ni/CNT catalysts is shifted upward with respect to that of 3-Ni/CNT, which indicates that the closer it is to the bottom of the conduction band, the better the conductivity, the more metallic pronounced, and its catalytic activity will be stronger [76]. The energy band calculations show that the energy gap values of 2-Ni/CNT are 0.14 eV and that of 3-Ni/CNT are 0.23 eV, and the decrease of the energy gap value shows the enhancement of the electrical conductivity, so the electrocatalytic performance of 2-Ni/CNT is stronger than that of 3-Ni/CNT. However, the charge densities at the Fermi energy level of the three catalysts, NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT and H2-Ni/CNT, whose carbon groups are phthalocyanine complexes and nanoribbons, are 55.13 eV, 119.97 eV and 120.38 eV. The NiPc/CNT catalyst has the smallest charge density at the Fermi energy level, and its catalytic activity is the smallest, while the NiPc/CNT energy gap values for H3-Ni/CNT and H2-Ni/CNT are reduced compared with the NiPc/CNT catalysts, so H3-Ni/CNT and H2-Ni/CNT are more electrically conductive than the NiPc/CNT catalysts. Catalytic activity is related to the number of nitrogen coordinations, in catalysts, nitrogen atoms can induce changes in the local electron density of the central metal atoms, which can to some extent affect the adsorption of reaction intermediates and regulate catalytic activity. The outstanding catalytic performance of NiN3-C with fewer nitrogen coordinations for CO2RR was demonstrated by Zhang et al. [77], underscoring the critical importance of the coordination microenvironment of single-atom Ni sites in electrocatalysis. Our results also indicate that the 2-Ni/CNT catalyst with lower coordination possesses superior catalytic activity. The nature of the catalytic activity of the five different catalysts was revealed by comparing their physical property characteristics separately. Competition of hydrogen evolution reactions Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is the main competitive reaction in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. In low pH electrolyte, the competitive reaction of HER is particularly obvious [78,79]. Here, we calculated and plotted the Gibbs free energy diagrams for the surface generation of *COOH, *OCHO and *H on five catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 7 . By calculating the free energy of the initial protonation steps and the initial proton electrification process of electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 *CO2+H ++e −→*COOH or *CO2+H ++e −→*OCHO and the free energy of the H ++e − initial protonation step of HER, the selectivity between electrocatalytic CO2RR and HER can be determined. According to the Sabatier principle, ΔGH* can characterize the reaction activity for HER, and the optimal value of |ΔGH*| should be close to zero [80]. For NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT, the free energy changes of HER are 1.59 eV, 2.72 eV, 2.18 eV, 0.51 eV and 0.14 eV, respectively. The free energy changes of *CO2+H ++e −→*COOH on NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT are 1.81 eV, 1.39 eV, 1.62 eV, 0.82 eV and 0.21 eV, respectively. The free energy changes of *CO2+H ++e −→*OCHO on the catalyst surface are 2.20 eV, 1.76 eV, 1.88 eV, 1.31 eV and 0.90 eV, respectively. It can be observed that the HER free energy of H3-Ni/CNT and H2-Ni/CNT catalysts changes greatly, indicating that the HER will be inhibited; while the opposite is true for three catalysts, NiPc/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT, suggesting that electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 reaction will be inhibited. Theoretically, in an acidic medium, the ΔGH* for 2-Ni/CNT approaches zero, indicating that the rate of the HER would increase, concurrently suppressing the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. However, our research findings reveal that both 3-Ni/CNT and 2-Ni/CNT can enhance the electrocatalytic performance for CO2 reduction. Therefore, during the electrocatalysis process, it is recommended to reduce the solution's acidity to minimize the occurrence of the HER, thus favoring the CO2RR [81,82]. Conclusion In this paper, the DFT calculation method is used to optimize the stable structures of five Ni-doped carbon-based single metal atom catalysts supported by carbon nanotubes, and calculate the electronic structure features and density of states. The corresponding carbon-based materials are Ni phthalocyanine complexes, tri-coordinated carbon nanoribbons, di-coordinated carbon nanoribbons, tri-coordinated graphene and di-coordinated graphene materials. We discuss the mechanism of electrochemical CO2 reduction process with NiPc/CNT, H3-Ni/CNT, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT catalysts. The order of activity of the five catalysts for electrocatalytic CO2 is 2-Ni/CNT>3-Ni/CNT>H3-Ni/CNT>H2-Ni/CNT>NiPc/CNT. NiPc/CNT and H3-Ni/CNT electrocatalyzed CO2 reduction to CO, and the activity of H3-Ni/CNT catalyst is stronger, which is consistent with the experimental results. Comparing the limiting potentials of these five catalysts, the electrocatalytic CO2 performance of our three newly designed catalysts, H2-Ni/CNT, 3-Ni/CNT, and 2-Ni/CNT, has been improved. Our results show that the 2-Ni/CNT catalyst has excellent electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance, which indicates that the atomically dispersed nickel site (Ni-Nx) has considerable activity for selective electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction. We simultaneously investigated the mechanism of competing HER in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 with five catalysts, and in order to inhibit the competing HER and improve the efficiency of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction, the acidity of the solution can be appropriately reduced. The results obtained in present work not only agree well with previous experimental work [52,83,84], but also provide some novel insights that can be helpful for future studies. Theoretically, this work emphasizes the importance of using more realistic models during the calculation, which may lead to very different results. Experimentally, the theoretical study on the CO2 reduction mechanisms with the designed novel carbon based single atom electrocatalysts can provide solid foundations for the future design of similar catalysts with better performances. coredata.dc:description: In this study, five Ni-doped carbon-based single metal atom catalysts supported by carbon nanotubes, which can be used for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, were constructed. According to their structures, these catalysts include one Ni phthalocyanine (NiPc) molecule, two di- and tri-coordinated Ni-doped carbon nanoribbons, and two di-/tri-coordination Ni-doped graphene, which are denoted as NiPc/CNT, H2(H3)-Ni/CNT, 2(3)-Ni/CNT respectively. We first optimized their structures and studied the adsorption characteristics of CO2 on these catalysts with PBE+D3 method. Additionally, the electronic structure characteristics were then calculated, and the electrocatalytic mechanisms of CO2 reduction to CO, HCOOH, CH3OH and CH4 using these catalysts were studied in detail. It is found that the electrocatalytic activities of these five catalysts for reducing CO2 follow the order of 2-Ni/CNT>3-Ni/CNT>H3-Ni/CNT>H2-Ni/CNT>NiPc/CNT. As can be seen, the di-coordination catalysts perform best, followed by the tri-coordination catalysts, while the four-coordination NiPc-based catalyst performs worst. Moreover, graphene-based materials have stronger catalytic activities than their nanoribbon counterparts. Apart from these facts, these five catalytic materials may exhibit product selectivity at different limiting potentials, and specific reaction products can therefore be synthesized by controlling the potentials. We simultaneously investigated the mechanism of competing hydrogen evolution reactions in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 with five catalysts, and in order to inhibit the competing hydrogen evolution reactions and improve the efficiency of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction, the acidity of the solution can be appropriately reduced. We hope that our present work can provide a theoretical foundation for the future design and synthesis of novel carbon-based electrocatalyst for efficient CO2 reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction mechanisms using carbon-nanotube-supported carbon-based single metal atom catalysts
